intro: Lepidium divaricatum var. subdentatum, commonly known as the narrow-leaved peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to parts of North America. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and has small, oval-shaped leaves with finely toothed margins. Its flowers are small, yellowish, and arranged in clusters, typical of the mustard family. The species is often found in grasslands and along roadsides, contributing to the ecological diversity of these habitats.
